_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Risk Management Plan - Executive Summary

Facility:    MFA Bulk Plant - Higginsville
Location:    West 24th Terrace, Higginsville, Mo.
Contact:     Bobby Owen
Phone:     660-584-3676


1. The Facility Policy

    MFA Incorporated and the employees of the MFA Bulk Plant in Higginsville are committed to the prevention of any accidental release of anhydrous ammonia. If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the Higginsville Fire Department, and other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.

2. Facility Information

The primary activity at the facility is the receiving, storage and distribution of bulk dry and liquid fertilizer and anhydrous ammonia for direct application as a crop nutrient. The facility also handles pesticides products.

The facility has (1) 30,000 gallon storage tank, (1) 12,000 gallon storage tank and the largest tank onsite would be a railroad tank car containing approximately 160,000 pounds. There may be occasions where two railroad tank cars would be located at the facility. The maximum quantity handled would be the unloading of a railroad tank car. The facility also has (45) 1,000 gallon nurse tanks for product distribution.  

3. The Accidental Release Prevention Program.

The facility has implemented the provisions of "Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, K-61.1, 1981", published by The American National Standards Institute, Inc., the Missouri Anhydrous Ammonia Law and the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and handling of Anhydrous Ammonia".

4. The Five-year Accident History

There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that: have caused any deaths, injuries, or significant property damage at the facility; nor to our knowledge, have resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage,

or environmental damage.

5. The Emergency Response Program.

The facility has;
    
      a. a written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA Standard, 29 CFR 1910.38;

    b. provided State and Local authorities with the emergency planning and community
          right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA);

    c. a written emergency response program, in accordance with OSHA Standard, 29 CFR
          1910.120, including pre-emergency planning and employee training.

6. Planned changes to improve safety.

Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility. Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions. The facility has been evaluated to meet the requirements of the ANSI K61.1999 Standard and upgrades will be made in the near future.


    6/11/08
